138001715.review:
I'm not a big V-tuber guy, I've seen clips and know of them but I'm not that dedicated to hollow live. but as someone who plays a decent amount of fighting games i became interested in this project.unfortunately i'm kinda mixed on the game, i think it has potential but its missing polish in the parts it really matters. I doubt the devs will see this but I really hope some of this feedback makes it back to them. I understand its a fan project so I'm not holding to the same standard of official releases, but I do hope the games issues I have got resolved.


 So let's start with some positives.


Pros

-[Surprisingly decent single player content.
 the difficulty feels kinda inconsistent. Like i picked harder enemies and the run was a total cakewalk until act 3 where enemies start doing 50% randomly. But aside from that it's a fine mode if a little mindless. I feel if there was a unique boss each act that could help break the repetition.]

-[solid training mode.
 Having a save state feature is rare, and appreciated]

-[Fan game
Obviously a love letter with lots of references. While i don't get most of them, the people who do probably enjoy them.]

-[its free and easy to download.
 It doesn't sound like a compliment, but when you've played a lot of obscure fighting games/mugens that require extra steps just to set up, a simple steam download is appreciated.]

-[The visuals. 
the pixel art looks pretty good at times and the UI looks clean if a little cluttered at times.]

Cons


-[ training mode bug?
The  training mode will randomly take 1-5 seconds to reload to neutral, and I don't know why because it feels random. Hopefully that gets fixed.](edit: this had been patched, good job)

.[Game feel. 
My biggest problem is the general feel of the game. The main issue is that the game feels very stiff. things like run jumping not caring momentum, and hit boxes feel off, having ground normal cancel chains but not air normal cancel chains, and many of the animations being kinda jank all makes the game feel clunky. The biggest issue I have is that momentum, it just feels bad.]

-[animation inconsistency.
Generally the game looks good. Although this isn't evenly distributed, some characters like Botan look very fluid while others like korrone seem to have been made early or got the short hand of the sick. Additionally I feel many of the moves lack impact, and it can feel like you're throwing around a wet noodle.]


-[Unclear balances. 
This section is less about ”X character is busted” and more so that I find the game and characters unsure of what they're trying to achieve. The game generally has very limited combo routes with low damage but has a burst? I understand that newcomers don't like to be combo’ed and you can use the burst to maintain block pressure, but it still feels out of places in this game, with the exception of Botan who is consistently doing 50% combos. while she's clearly a unintended outlier, I ask do you want this game to be a grounded low damage footsie game or a high damage assist fighter, because it's unclear at the moment? 

The assists seemed to be designed for neutral control  rather than combo extension. but considering the meter requirement some seem clearly better and more flexible at that than others. Also the colab supers are not explained well and are unclear how they work. They could have better descriptions

Character playstyles feel a bit undefined. Like botan is supposed to be a large, high damage zoner with the grenade damages being as is. But she has, good run speed, fast disjointed buttons, one of the best jump-ins in j2c, and looping close range block pressure(witch currently only loses to Invincible moves with how plus it is) which makes her a better rushdown character than Ayane, the actual rushdown  character.

Additionally Soras is supposed to be a setplay character which implys shes supposed to get a loping mix of her knockdowns, which is implied by her having a 6c overhead, and an oki fireball. However her 5m,6m, and jm combined with her 2 other fireballs, and projectile reflect makes a way more effective zoner than arguably botan, because Botans full screen guard pressure mostly loses to jump in air block, (aside from the chip you take).

While I could go on, what I'm trying to get at is the playstyles could be more defined in achieving a specific goal, so it's easier to understand what each character trying to achieve.]

-[other character bugs? 
Hears some of the stuff i found
Kokos otg grab turns the character around for a few frames, the grabs minus but if the player tries to punish too early they get a button that's facing the wrong way. I don't know if that's intentional but it feels jank.
Soras Oki fireball last between rounds , and can hit round start

Not recommending this game is odd because it's literally free so you're only wasting time if you don't like it.But this game has problems that i would like to be fixed. but I hope for the best for this game and get the polish it needs. It's doing well right now so for the devs sake I hope they can deliver on a great fighting game. The potential is hear it just need more time in the oven

137987829.review:
[h1]Very fun fighter with lots of personality. Holds up decently well for experienced Fighting-Game fans[/h1]

[i]TL;DR If the screenshots/videos look fun, try it. However, it is very buggy, and not balanced.[/i]

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Huge attention to detail, many references and voice lines.
[*]Unique cast of characters. No copy pasted characters from other fighters.
[*]Lots of room to explore. New tech and combos are discovered every day.
[*]Good implementation of rollback netcode.
[*]Robust single-player mode (that I have not touched).
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Extremely buggy. Bugs include things like post-round damage and button lock-outs.
[*]Extremely unpolished mechanics. The developers do not seem to understand certain fundamental aspects of fighters. The frame data is baffling, throws can only be teched after they connect, and the hitboxes are exceptionally huge. Imagine if Ryu's tatsu covered his whole body and then some.
[/list]

[b]Mixed:[/b]
[list]
[*]Asthetics. This game is very anime, and the fighters are all idols. May not be for everyone.
[*]No ranked mode. Despite having ~6k players on at-the-time, I almost always use the Discord to find my matches, as there is no other way of consistently finding an opponent of comparable skill. The Discord may be found on the Mizuumi wiki for the game.
[/list]

[b]Conclusion[/b]
[i]Idol Showdown[/i] is a very fun game. Casual VTuber fans will find the game's singleplayer content enjoyable, and can have fun mashing online with other newcomers. Veterans will find an uncut gem. There is a lot to like here, and the discovery process can make it feel like you are playing a fighting game from the old-days, where things were broken and gameplay was emergent. However, it can feel like Mugen at times. It's free, and a lot of care was put into the project, so I would recommend giving it a shot.

As I write this watching the Idol Showdown replay of the stream as the real Korone plays, (who is my most favorite character), and I love Gura and one Vtuber who had the best personality from VOMS, Pikamee, it is a really good game that is free. The sound effects or voice overs were not the same voice actresses, but I've learned Botan provided for the game.  

The mechanics connect well, and as chaotic as MVSC 2, but for two years making this, it's a real achievement.  I hope to work with BESTO games in the future for an Atarashii Gakko fighting game.  

There's a learning curve but I would say just try to be patient with labbing the tutorials and make your own combos.  I hope the real Korone actress will fight with me one day since I added her to my friends list.

137981346.review:
The game has a decent foundation for a fighting game but the single player mode has so many bugs. The online is yes in a beta and in its current state, the netcode is terrible, even with "close" matches with others. The lobby system barely works with issues joining lobbies hanging on "Attempting to connect to an Opponent" and the rollback netcode with random stutters and slowdowns vs opponents with 100ms ping and about 2-3 frames of rollback.

The game itself is pretty fun but its annoying to not start with burst at the start of a match, which just causes people to play crazy aggressive and the mechanics really lean on a huge amount of offense with almost no defensive mechanics that are in this type of psudo air dasher genere.

I would recommend the game if you're new to fighting games but I hope they fix and update these problems in the future along with reshaping some of the mechanics.

137978731.review:
As a more casual fighting game fan (I've played my fair share, but am never interested in online/competitive) I can't speak for how well designed/made this game is on a competitive level, but it is fun as hell. Just in terms of gameplay alone it's very easy to pick up and feels good to play (inputs are responsive, even in online), the characters have a nice variety of move sets, there are some neat mechanics I've not seen in other fighting games. There's not loads of content yet, but there's enough depth that it doesn't really matter (and there's plenty of room for more characters).

As a free fan-made game, it's incredibly impressive. The attention to detail, representation of the characters, easter eggs and references, everything that you'd expect from a dedicated fan game but with the quality of something official. AND it's free, amazing. 

9/10 Yubis, because one got taken off with a chainsaw.

137978170.review:
[h1] A Labour of Love [/h1]
This free fan game is better than it has any right to be, it is a great love letter to Hololive. The gameplay is fun, has interesting mechanics, and is pretty beginner friendly for the genre.

[h1] Still janky [/h1]
That being said, still pretty janky and buggy. For example, as of the time I am writing this review, Coco's command grabs can be teched (for those unfamiliar with fighting games, you're not supposed to be able to do that, scary command grabs is what makes grapplers threatening).

At least the devs are very actively fixing the game, so I am still giving it a positive review.

[h1] Suggestions for the devs [/h1]
[list]
    [*]Fix Coco, I'm not even a Coco main but this is really a massive oversight. *Edit, Coco is now fixed, nice*
    [*]Add a retry feature to the Arcade mode, so players can challenge it again with the same character set-up instead of being booted back to the character select screen.
    [*]Perhaps add the feature to save a character set-up? Currently it is still "fine", but as more characters get added in the future, it'll be kinda annoying to pick your character, palette, and collab over and over.
    [*]I wish that I can see my Virtual Frontier collection in a more convenient way. A button to visit [spoiler] Kureiji Ollie [/spoiler] right after a Frontier run would do.
[/list]

137972397.review:
tl;dr As a fan game, it's cute. As a fighting game, it is too focused on offense and provides little support for defensive players

The game is snappy and doesn't limit the player offensively. If you can think of it, there's probably a way to do it. The game is very loose, and that's a good thing.

I mostly played Aki and was having a decent time labbing her and took her online to get a pretty decent win loss record, although I couldn't tell you what it is because that info doesn't appear to be viewable. The lobbies are horrendous but the actual online feel of the game is pretty good.

I feel some of the characters are mislabled as Aki is labeled as a zoner but has terrible projectiles and weird disjointed attacks. I feel, at least at this time, she is most effective as a mix up character. Her command normals are pretty good and Mukirose buttons feel good and lead to a ton of damage. She has no reversals though, so if you get hit, be prepared to block for the rest of your life, but good news, it won't last long. Her heavy TP is supposed to be invincible but I couldn't tell you when or how long because it's always getting stuffed. That may be a skill issue.

The game direction seems all over the place at times where sometimes I'm learning and having fun, and the next I'm struggling to understand the game mechanics, or rather why some things are the way they are.

For example, the game has a burst meter but you have to earn it. You don't start off with it and it's a little frustrating but I got over that pretty quickly. Also for as fast as this game is, I am shocked that there's not a push block or alpha counter of any type.

Currently this game rewards aggression in such a frustrating way. Defensive characters have to rely on their ability to block because the game does not reward you for good defense. 

Assists, or Collabs in this game, are also tied to meter which make them kind of annoying to use and I often just ignore them. Also they cannot be used while other buttons are being pressed so they're mostly being used during wall bounce or hard knockdown. 
The exception being that your Collabs also have supers and can be used easily mid combo. I think both the regular collab and the super collab cost meter though. I used regular collabs so little that I can't recall if it cost anything.

I didn't touch the single player so I can't tell you here or there on if it's fun.

The devs seem highly responsive though and are actively looking through streams for feedback which is nice. I might revisit this game down the road when the online gets out of beta but currently I'm not very thrilled with the game mechanically.

137969470.review:
I went through the tutorial. Seemed fine with the controls. Went into a match against an *easy* AI, and could not land any attacks because the hitboxes are extremely off, the AI somehow always knew when to grab counter (on easy), never failed to land their grabs because grab cancels weren't in the tutorial, and the input detection is wonky as all hell, deciding to ruin quarter-circle inputs by dragging out the diagonal input three times over before finally deciding i had let go of the horizontal direction.
I have played fighting games before, and I am perfectly capable of doing quartercircle inputs in them. When I played this it felt like I only landed quarter-circle inputs in this game when it felt like *allowing* me to land one.

The sprites are fine, the subject matter is fine, i don't care whether someone likes Vtubers or not. But the hitboxes and input detection is genuinely to worst I've personally experienced. When someone who goes through the tutorial to learn the control scheme and has played fighting games prior cannot beat an EASY AI even after going through the tutorial AGAIN and going into training to try to figure out a single low-difficulty character and their moves, then the game needs some kind of tuning.

137962259.review:
Idol Showdown is a fantastic fighting game that's packed with Hololive goodness. As a fan of both the Hololive characters and fighting games, I was immediately drawn to this game, and it did not disappoint. The game features a great roster of characters with their unique moves and personalities, which makes it feel like you're really playing as your favorite VTuber.

What I love most about Idol Showdown is the amount of attention to detail that went into the game. From the various stages to the background music, everything feels like it was carefully crafted to make the game an immersive experience. I also appreciate the nods to Hololive memes and references scattered throughout the game. It's clear that the devs are fans themselves and put a lot of love into this project.

Overall, I highly recommend Idol Showdown to anyone who loves Hololive and fighting games. It's a great way to experience the world of Hololive in a new and exciting way, and I'm looking forward to seeing what the devs have in store for the game's future updates.

137960343.review:
If you aren't a fan of HoloLive, this is a very basic, enjoyable, quirky fighting game. You'll probably have fun with it even if you're new to fighting game, since it has a really low skill floor and one button special moves. However, for those of you with more experience, it rewards you with a special meter if you perform moves with actual fighting game commands, which you can then use to cancel special moves into other special moves or supers. For someone like me who loves fighting games but doesn't like to spend hours labbing combos, this is perfect.

If you ARE into HoloLive, you have nothing to lose if you grab this game. It's free, it's full of charm, it'll make you laugh and smile, and it even has a great soundtrack (as one would expect from a comedi--err, idol company)! If you like fighting games and HoloLive, then this game will be a super fun experience for you! If you just like HoloLive and have never touched a fighting game, well... giving the game a shot totally won't hurt, haha.

137960070.review:
This game is pretty good. The Virtual Frontier mode, which is basically Slay the Spire but a fighting game instead of a card game, makes it replayable for people who don't just want to spend hours in the lab. 

It serves as a secondary tutorial for players to `get good` and prepare them for real online matches. The tutorial could use some work. A combo trial would go a long way for honers to practice the most optimal combos and also the online could use two more additions, namely an auto match making system and a tournament mode (with spectator capabilities).

However, I do have some minor gripes. I can't sell items in the Virtual Frontier shops, even if it feels like I should. It just feels annoying to see that I'm missing like 10-20 pekos to buy an item I really want. If you're concerned about being able to sell the negative items, then just make it so that ERROR items cannot be sold. Another gripe is the AI bot. While it's possible to cheese the living hell out of them, the Very Hard Korone AI made me want to open twitter and go through the dictionary of unspeakables. 

Other than that, it's a great game. 9/10, would recommend.

I will be looking forward to future updates and games from the devs <3

137959492.review:
The dudes who made this game probably sat down in a bar together and said drunkingly;

"Hey...lets uhhh...make a fighting game based off of uhhh....V-Tubers...yeah....but make it actually good...and entirely free."

And they did just that, and made a fighter that is on-par with what you would expect from the most played fighters on Steam, and made it cost a whopping $0 with Roll-Back netcode straight out of the box. (Something that not even all AAA fighters have upon release. Looking at you Dragon Ball FighterZ and DNF Duel.)

That and along with the gorgeous pixel-art, the references and love for the source material, and all of the small things that makes it a lot more inviting and welcoming to new players, makes this game one of the best fighters you can pick up and play right now as a Fighting Game Veteran, a Fighting Game Fledgling,  or someone who just likes Hololive.

137958800.review:
Only played a couple hours so far, but it's insane how good this is.  The fighting system is really easy to pick up, but there is depth to be found in the supers and assists.  I've managed to get an almost 50% combo with Botan after like 10 minutes of messing around.  

The couple of online matches I played felt really good, better than a lot of AAA fighting games over the past decade or so at launch, and there's a pretty nice training mode with bot settings and a record function.  The 4 stages are nice and jammed with references, and the overall presentation of the game is just top notch, from character portraits, to the sprite animations, to things like the win screen pulling out to reveal it's being streamed with chat going on to the right.

I can't recommend this enough, it blows my mind that a fan made fighting game is this good, and I hope to see a lot more characters in the future!

137956643.review:
Very happy with how it turned out. The gameplay is akin to Dengeki Bunko: Fighting Climax, so if you're part of the specific minority who play(ed) that series, you have an idea of what's in store. You take a main fighter and an assist into the fray and duke it out against an opponent. The tutorial is straightforward and gives players the general idea of how the game operates.

The art is great and so are the memes (like seriously, I get to see SEISO in all its glory as five golden letters). Each character's gameplay design is interesting, if not at the very least fitting with their personae. Fubuki's basically Guile with guardpoint and a gacha mechanic, MiComet is impressively oppressive, Botan/Iroha just makes sense as a team... The few hours I've spent just trying out the characters have been a blast, just trying to find pairs that fit my playstyle and work well together.

Go as crazy as you want with the game, or not. As for what I think about the game, well... The blue thumb above the post speaks for itself.

137933430.review:
I don't really know anything about fighting games but I do love hololive so I figured I'd try this out anyway. Due to the not knowing anything about fighting games, I am distinctly not good at it and am literally just mashing buttons hoping that I win, but even with that it's pretty fun! It feels very accessible as a beginner, with a "very easy" difficulty setting and helpful tutorials that teach concepts that a fighting game that favored its more advanced players may just expect you to know already. It also has options in Virtual Frontier to set you items to auto, which is probably a horrible strategy but, again, as a huge beginner I wouldn't know when to use them and would probably end up ignoring them without this option, so it's greatly appreciated. It advertises its beginner-friendliness and delivers. I was actually able to win fights! I will die before I do an actual PvP battle, though. PvAI for me forever, thank you.

Aside from the gameplay, the art is absolutely amazing, the animations do a fantastic job of capturing the girls' personalities and are just lovely to watch, the music and sounds add to the already fun atmosphere, it's just a well-made game by all accounts. And for free! You can really tell that a lot went into this project, not to mention the mach 10 update speed. It's clear that a lot of love went into this and it really paid off in the final product. I just hope the dev team kept [i]some[/i] of their blood, sweat, and tears.

It's great as a fighting game as far as I can tell and it's definitely great as a hololive fan game. At this price, you'd be remiss not to give it a shot.

also obligatory yubi yubi

137924334.review:
I have no idea what "hololive" is or why these anime girls are doing nonsensical things as attacks, so I'm looking at this purely as a fighting game, and as a fighting game, it's pretty good! Just a bit jank. A lot of hit boxes seems weird and the training mode doesn't seem to be the best (i.e no frame data), but there's some fun to be had. I'm not sure about the balance so far, but I played the oni girl with the two swords (got Zoro vibes from her) and she seemed to do pretty well against the rest of the cast. You also have MVC1 style assists to help with match ups or just to do stylish combos. I do want to say that the netcode, despite being GGPO isn't the greatest. I've had some nasty rollback issues, but I might chalk that up due to my opponent not having a good computer/connection.

As it stands this a decent enough fighting game that seems to be a nice middle ground between grounded based games and air dashers. I would say give it a go! It's free anyways!

137922492.review:
I've been a competitive fighting game player for about 18 years now, and really, Idol Showdown is a blast in several refreshing ways and also super enjoyable as a Hololive fan. I was blessed to be able to beta test this game and had a lot of fun finding things, so it has a lot for the sweats, but the single player offerings are also just excellent, even compared among modern paid games. Virtual Frontier is amazing.

The game is pretty approachable with simple controls available, but even the full motion inputs are not complicated (the hardest being a hadoken input). The hardest thing to get down is understanding the resources and their management, as well as general fighting game concepts, but that mostly comes from just playing.

I feel that fans of fighting games and fans of vtubers will both enjoy this game with no previous experience in one of the two areas - there's just a lot for both sides. The personality and charm of the game with the high quality of its assets and design really shine through. It's a gift to us all

I hope that through this, the fg community and vtuber fans can connect and make friends. I would love to see that. It has also been great so far seeing the talents themselves play the game, and i'm excited to see what the future holds for it.

137922242.review: Fast and hectic.  Execution is a bit high for me.  Online opponents range from casual fans who've never played a fighting game before and anime fighter vets who have impeccable execution.  It's a pretty good fighting game, though none of my friends play the genre much anymore.

137920258.review:
Game is quite fun and is an extremely solid product for a free game. It's online is in beta but it works pretty well with people of the same region. It has some bugs, but those are going to eventually be fixed. Dev Team are paying attention to any infinites possible and are patching them as soon as possible. I really recommend for players who never played a fighting game before and doesn't want to buy a full price game. It's easy to pick up but it looks like it might have a nice ceiling of difficulty. Time will tell if I'm right or not. Also, single player is really fun to play. 

As someone who loves Blazblue CF and Melty Blood, this game is awesome even though it doesn't nearly feel like that (it feels like a Granblue Fantasy Versus with more complex combos).

The training mode could be better though. It's quite difficult to lab new stuff in it's current state. I trust they'll improve it once the polish the online.

Also, they plan to add four new characters for FREE. 

On a side note, I would love to play Korone, but she's a Shoto and it's too honest (like real Korone) so I'm maining Suisei.

137916453.review: This is probably one of the best fan made fighting games out there the amount of love and passion in its characters, lore, references, and gameplay makes a fun Time for hololive fans and fighting games fans. The inspiration of guilty gear, BlazBlue l, under night , and granblue makes me smile from ear to ear. There a few bugs here and there like how some combos only work on certain characters (don't know if that's intentional or not) some graphical glitches here and there and some odd online glitches in which my opponent losing their life but able to control there character when the camera zooms in only to win the round. 137912591.review:
Things in this game that work:
- References to Hololive talent and culture in general. It's very clear that this is a project made with a lot of love, which gives the game a lot of charm.
- Animations. Beautiful pixel art and effects give each round a very vibrant feel.
- Sound design. The voice lines and music remixes give this game way more polish than it has any right to have.
- Balance between depth and newcomer friendliness. I was skeptical of the special button, but it won me over quickly as a good way to help bridge the gap between new and veteran fighting game players.

Nitpicks/suggestions:
- Suisei feels undertuned in terms of frame data. She doesn't need to be a Melty Blood character, but her attacks need either more range or slightly less lag if she's going to be able to compete in the same game as the current top tiers (Botan, Sora, Korone).
- Burst feels very polarizing. Certain characters get punished significantly harder by having their combo ended than others (cough, Botan).
- Korone straight up needs more lag. 1/2 additional frames per attack would help bring her in line without ruining her.
- Botan's damage should be brought more in line. As it currently sits, her potential damage per combo is too high for how safe her gameplan is.
- Collabs feel clunky, but the system itself is a very interesting take on the traditional assist system.

Overall, for a free fan-made game, there isn't a lot to actually complain about for Idol Showdown. I'm excited to see this game continue to receive updates as the devs seem very in tune with the community. It isn't a perfect package, but any serious balance issues that arise can always be patched later. The systems largely work as intended, and the polish in the package is worth well above the price of admission.

Grade: B+

137910685.review:
Editing the review after a bit more playtime. know two things before my review.
1: the game is both player friendly and free. costs nothing to try it out for yourself, a create your own opinion about it. the game will welcome you.
2: I am not a big Fighting games player. i do not do korean wavedashes and i don't do combos in another combo with a super but that combo isn't laming any combos but in the end it's still a combo. i'm a Casual who just want to have fun.

Now:
First thing that came to mind. The soudtrack and sound effects are outstanding. so much so i thought to myself "Even SF5 has a shrilly earpiercer which i have to mute from the first minute. this is a free passion project. it didn't deserve having guilty gear strive-tier music." later i've seen it's deserved.

second: The game has a real tutorial. not a "this is how you block, this is hadoken, this is how you hit, good luck playing Vega" no. Idol showdown took Guilty gear as an example. every character has the same inputs, every character can cancel, every character has the same base inputs. and the tutorial teaches you everything you need to know for playing the game. you won't necessarily be great (lemme reiterate, i blow chunks, i get folded by AIs on normal) but you'll be able to play the damned game, and learn every necessary input you'll need later from the moment you start playing the tutorial. and that is awesome.

Third: the game is filled to the brim with references. Ayame with her trademark couch-destroying club swing, having a brawl with her clones saying "Yo Dayo" (translated by i'm the real one). Coco Kaichou being rude, bossy but loveable, reviewing meme, riding a dino like in Ark, and the reference to Asacoco with the Plug-in type AsaCoCo. Roboco being a cutesy military robot, with a huge gap moe between her smile her "Hallobo!" and the 12 ICBMs she just shot directly into your cranium, Miko being an adorable klutz even when playing minecraft. and so many more even in music themes being mostly Hololive song, credits theme being a reference to the cutest miko playing ark.

Fourth while some would have thought "okay i made my passion project, it's good, it's simple enough, it has references" and call it a day, The dev team looked at tihs and said "No" and created Arcade mode. a kind of Rogue-styled gamemode. with unique items proper to this mode (emotional support Plastic ball my go-to), adorable references to the whole hololive roster and world. and even GRINDING.
they made skins, called Cosplays here. everybody has 3 besides default. but you can grind in game to recieve another. no one is left out. everybody has some ability to look a bit cooler if they don't particularly like default. but if someone grinds he can recieve a reward to flex a bit? now that is cool. flexers are rewarded, players are not left out.

to conclude, Idol Showdown is a 10/10. the best Fighting game i've played besides Guilty gear Strive which costs 100 dollars for full experience.
Idol showdown is Free.  it's made by loving people passionate about Hololive. it's the most user friendly fighting game i've ever played, no competition even comes close to its simple and intuitive tutorial and control scheme without 5 hours spreadsheet reading or distractions like Street fighter or Skullgirls.
Sound design is just perfect, nothing to add, hits sound good, themes sound good without distracting.
and Idol showdown is filled with fun and care, even for a non-hololive-fan player.
If ever, in your life, you get a choice to have a fighting game experience to try in your existence on earth, take that opportunity, this one is the one you might want to look at for a fun, simple and tight experience.

137904001.review:
Game is legit pretty damn fun and solid. Just give them a few patches to fix the bugs, and if better lobbies and matchmaking get implemented (no spectator mode for streaming tournaments is tragic), then it can really shine. Also the single-player Virtual Frontier mode is already one of my standouts on coolest fighting game single player modes. Reminds me of Guilty Gear's M.O.M. mode. Very neat thing for new and casual fighting game players.

Only real gripe aside from that is that having a ground magic series, jump canceled launchers, but no air magic series feels really off.
Edit: After a few (a lot) more hours, another gripe I have is that getting hit or blocking builds next to no meter while certain characters can build 1-2 bars and Superchat meter from their combo routes. That, and the only real defensive options are Burst, certain assists, and characters with Reversal supers, but that runs into the issue of meter not being built on hit/block. Other than that, my opinion of the game has risen even higher since I put more hours into it, it's incredibly fun and the devs did a wonderful job on making an enjoyable system and characters.

137901931.review:
Tentative recommend. I don't know much about hololive, but the game feels pretty good. Animations are good. There are definitely tons of references I accept I'm not going to get. 

The Good:
Animations are good.
Everything's responsive.
Good mechanics like perfect guard.
I like the assist mechanic.
The rogue-lite mode is fantastic, and the bulk of why I am recommending. As a fan of both fighting games and rogue-lite progression, I can definitely see myself playing more of it. 

The Bad:
There are just too many functions crammed into the game. It's a four button fighter but it has dedicated buttons for:

Burst
Assist
Item (3 options, which map to a dedicated Item button+L/M/H)
Special

You have throw using either dedicated or two button combo. So you either have to use additional dedicated buttons, or you have to do some jank button combos that don't feel natural. If your game can't fit all it's inputs on 6 buttons, you're trying to do to much. Having to simultaneously hit RT+L/M on a gamepad may be fine. On an arcade stick or fightpad, it's incredibly uncomfortable. Also there are button combinations that don't feel good on pad either, like L+H being on opposite face buttons. Think Item usage could have just been holding the special button and tapping a direction or something, but they decided to make both motion and directional inputs in one control scheme instead of just having the option of simple vs motion controls. So Special is another dedicated button that just doesn't have to be a dedicated buttonm, using precious real-estate in a game that wants both burst and assists. Which is doubly annoying since there are no complex inputs. Everything is a quarter circle or down+down input. So it's not like players have to learn pretzeling or even shoryu/Z motions.

May be minor issue/early game bugs, but hitboxes seem a bit strange. I used Botan's QCB-M rifle which has a weird angle, and watched the builled go right through the middle of a jumping character more than once with no hit or block animation. 

Overall:

It's free, so nothing to lose, and the rogue-like mode is worth the price of admission, but I probably won't put too much time into it because it physically hurts my button hand to play this on an arcade stick.

137895921.review:
The attacks ARE actually simple, it's a bit odd to get used to since theirs no kick and punch, just L M and H but so I'll be doing a combo, forget theirs no kick and then just press the wrong button.

As the game is still new, it's got a couple bugs, namely if you press certain menu stuff too fast or where your keys don't bind properly, like my down button being changed to G and staying that way for some reason as well as Botan's H gun shot despite there being no gun, but other then these couple of things, there's nothing too buggy.

The downside though is when you try to fight online, your ping can soar from 50 to 200 before you know it, and before the game inevitably boots you for being too laggy, you'll be experiencing the world in slow motion, meaning two people are fighting in slow motion slowly flying towards each other like they're in a movie.

The game under normal circumstances is incredibly fast so getting used to both speeds is tough (for me anywayze), so they'll have to fix this part.

And finally, the references in this game are, well, a lot, all the maps have a reference and are true (like "say ara ara") so you won't be disappointed on that end and more then a few have made me laugh.

Overall, 4/5 stars, missing one for the online thing, would be half a star lower if I cared more about the online thing, otherwise it's a fun game.

137887752.review:
This may be the easiest fighting game I have ever been able to play. Don't get me wrong; easy as in easy to learn but hard to master since everybody will have an even playing field with the simple control and command input. A bit of info about this game for any newcomer: Idol Showdown is a fighting game project with roster based-on Hololive members -aka Vtubers-  which is popular on social media. The game currently will feature 8 characters that represent certain archetypes from fighting game such as Korone (shoto or the jack of all trade); Coco (grappler); Botan (zoner hybrid); Ayame (rushdown)...and other 4 characters that I haven't learnt properly yet. This create the feeling of diversity in playstyles despite the rather temporary limited roster and this is a plus from me. 

From the point of presentation; the game stay close with the early 2000s FGs (fighting games) such as King of Fighters 2002 Unlimited match with the 16 bits character design; which is rather simple compare to other modern FG titles. Yet simple but effective; this allows low-en PC can handle this game just fine. Another plus from me.

Since I haven't mention the control scheme I will put it here. The control consist of 6 buttons (not including shortcut buttons) : Light Attack; Medium Attack; Heavy Attack; Special Attack; Collabs (assist) and Burst (GTFO me button). And why do I say it is easy? With any character you can string 3 basic attack from Light to Heavy and/or into Special very consistently; so you dont have to worry too much about the way how to handle combos with each and every character every time; you can just jump in and take them for a spin and still able to pull off decent combos; but that doesn't make the game boring or way too easy; since you can practically cancel a lot of move; this will open for a variety of combos and mix-ups for you to try out; it's just a matter of experiment and testing for anyone who wants to play competitively and get-gud. So it's a good mix for both casual and hardcore players; and that's another point from me.

Regarding the downside of the game I'll put them here in the last part; the online feature which I play mostly is still inconsistent with the ping and packet loss makes playing outside of your own country a problem; for a fighting game this is not good but considering the Devs are not allow to make money from this game due to it being a fan project makes me wonder how on God's name are they able to maintain the server infrastructure in the long run. Secondly; the small roster of characters which is not a problem for me; maybe for someone else and it will be updated overtime. 

I hope whoever find this review useful will enjoy the game as much as I do; and support the game however way you can. This is a passion project that has potential to be big. GLHF!

137885300.review:
Amazing. Can't argue with the price what so ever, it's free. But I would honestly pay $10 if not more for it.
The gameplay feels like Melty Blood Type Lumina mixed with DNF duel and a hint of Street Fighter.

The people behind this game, you can tell, they are competent, and seem to have come a long way from the start of the development and I was quite suprised that they produced so much quality while not losing focus on what the game was going to be. And it's still free. You can see a lot of love and care was put in, while also making it accessible to non-fighting game players.

Although, the game currently on launch did come out with a lot of bugs and possibly even exploits I have yet to see, I am completely contempt and frankly over it, as I expect the game would likely get better and better if the developers give the same amount of care in the future as they did for the game before. Even with bugs, if you look beyond it, you can see that this is a genuine fighting game with existing and interesting mechanics.

Thank you very much, Team Besto Games.

137873622.review:
I've been excited to play this game ever since I saw it in the upcoming section on Steam.

It's a great middle ground between Guilty Gear and BlazBlue in terms of play.
Along with the usual archetypes of brawler, shoto-like, grappler, and zoner, Idol Showdown brings to the table unique character designs that are easily accessible due to the simplistic controls of the game.

----------------------------------------------------

GAMEPLAY:
Amazing. The responsiveness of the button presses as well as the movement are fluid and let me feel like I'm the one in control of the character.
I love how the characters interact and how hard hitting the moves feel. Korone's 5H, Coco's sweep, and Suisei's 6H feel so impactful.

----------------------------------------------------

CHARACTERS:
Every character has the following (at minimum):
- One QCF/236 special attack
- One QCB/214 special attack
- One DownDown/22 special attack
- Meter EX of each of the previous attacks
- Super that can be accessed with QCF+S
- At least one command normal

Although all of the characters have nearly the same inputs, there is variety. Kiryu Coco for example has some extra command throws, Tokino Sora has some activate-again abilities, and Shirakami Fubiki has a luck/gacha mechanic built in.
My personal favorite characters are: Inugami Korone, Shishiro Botan, and Hoshimachi Suisei (and Coco, but I'm bad at spacing)

----------------------------------------------------

ASSISTS:
For the assists, there is a wide selection of options. From straight up damage, to debuffs, to forced movement, Idol Showdown brings in good ideas for fighting game assists. HOWEVER, I feel there needs to be a gallery that shows what each assist does. While there is a name for the move, it does not describe the action very well. We need graphics!

My favorite assists are: Amane Kanata, Roboco, and Houshou Marine.
I run Kanata for Botan to keep zoning pressure, Roboco for general pressure and Iron Man style laser, and Marine for Coco.
To highlight Marine/Coco, Marine seems to prevent backdashing, so she lets Coco get in to Dragon Drop. Very strong combo. Any grappler player should consider this!

----------------------------------------------------

STAGES:
Stages in Idol Showdown are works of art. They've got the references, they've got the culture, they've got spirit.
The music of the stages are great as well!
The unfortunate part of the stages is... the lack of them! There are four stages in Idol Showdown and while they're all great, I wish there were more. It would also be nice to have them randomize per match (like how Dead or Alive 6 does it, where it randomizes with rematch).
Personal favorite stage: Midnight Rose

----------------------------------------------------

NETPLAY and CONTENT:
Idol Showdown's rollback netcode has worked great for me, although I've only played against one person in the time I've spent. In the matches, we never experienced any issues. One thing I'd like to see is a true lobby system to be able to spectate players as well as queue up with friends. Perhaps a system like Guilty Gear: -Strive- or Mortal Kombat 11 would work well.

For content, Idol Showdown actually has a decent amount to offer! Of course you can do the standard 1v1 PCP offline and online, but for solo content, there's Player vs AI, Arcade, and Virtual Frontier. 
Player vs AI is what you think it is. Arcade is the standard fighting game gauntlet. There's also a training mode with a very good tutorial. I suggest all new players check that out.

Virtual Frontier is the interesting part of these modes. It's a fighting game story mode visual novel that incorporates a unique mechanic, items! These items are seemingly exclusive to the mode, but I may be wrong. You can view what it's like in the trailer. I won't spoil anything about it, but it's definitely worth checking out!

Lastly, there are unlockable skin variants. I have yet to get to achieving any of these, but I figure they're accessible through Virtual Frontier.

------------------------------------

ART:
As expected, the characters in the game are from the HoloLive project. The portraits, pixel art, and animations are done very well. Every character has a unique style based around the individual VTuber.
I find the animation to be extremely fluid and easy on the eyes. There haven't been many situations where I've felt something just "came out of nowhere."
The portraits represent the characters in a fighting game atmosphere well, but I feel there should be multiple artists brought in so that players can choose alternate portraits to represent their favorite characters. Tekken 7 did this very well, especially with the season 4 free DLC that added more portrait art from the community.

----------------------------------------------------

Overall rating: 8/10
In it's current state, Idol Showdown receives a strong 8 from me. The things preventing it from being a 10 out of 10 are:
- Lack of stages (I'm sure more will be added and I'll update my review)
- Small bugs here and there that cause the game to fail/not load matches
- No lobby system
- No clear explanation/visualization of what assists do without testing them in-game

I feel Idol Showdown has a lot of potential as a side event at fighting game majors. I will be pushing to have this game be played at locals in my city.

137869326.review:
Idol Showdown is an all around impressive package. If you are a Hololive fan and new to fighting games, it's relatively easy to pick up with one button fireballs, easy special move inputs and pretty much every character having some form of light>medium>heavy combo.
For more experienced players, the game has a lot of depth and wacky combos to discover.

About the game modes:

Training is very impressive and has most of the features you would expect from a AAA game. I'm a casual player so I can't really point out any features it lacks.

Arcade feels like it's easier to beat with some characters than others, or maybe I'm just better at some of the characters. Either way, difficulty select for the Arcade mode would be nice.

Virtual Frontier is very much like the World of Light from Smash Ultimate, with fights having all sort of different modifiers to spice up the usual gameplay. There's a lot of unlockable items and references to find here. It's a nice challenge!

Online currently doesn't have matchmaking but connecting directly with a friend and duking it out is very seamless. In game, I didn't notice any issues with netcode. That said we were playing on very low ping. The game also encountered an error, but only after about 20 games. In summary, the online works better than in most big fighting game releases on launch.

Overall, the game is amazing. It's clearly a labor of love and way better than it has any reason to be for the price of FREE. This is a hell of a thing to put on the portfolio of everyone who worked on it, great job devs!

137869179.review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Felt the need to add to my review now because YES, they ARE indeed adding more characters, more assists, and more stages. Ever since this review, there's been so much more added to the game, whether in its singleplayer, fixes to balance, and at the time of writing, PEKORA, THE WAR CRIMINAL, WHO'S GONNA BE MY MAIN NOW REGARDLESS OF HOW BROKEN OR HOW BAD SHE ENDS UP, plus two more characters on the way. The support for this has been constant, both from the devs and the community. Seeing the FGC get into it has been wonderful, and even seeing a few of them fall into the Hololive rabbit hole has been both hilarious and wholesome. This game ain't gonna die any time soon, and all this has continued to keep this up there as one of, if not the BEST fan project I've ever seen and played.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

Considering this is a fan project, I don't know how much or if it even will expand to have more stages or more characters in its roster down the line, but with the great work already on display here with the Hololive talents they've featured in terms of their design, move sets, and quirks, it's almost criminal that this game's free.

If you're not a Hololive fan, you're not gonna be lost: what you got here is a solid fighting game with a small but incredibly distinct and fun character roster with a lot of crazy unique moves. And if you ARE a Hololive fan, you're gonna love all the references to in-jokes, memes, the attention to detail in the stages, and the fact that the girls are voiced using what I'm pretty sure are lines taken from streams the vtubers have done over the years. And Suisei going "Hi honey~" is probably gonna do things for you. It certainly does for me.

Also, it's got rollback. Besto Games, you madlads. There's big budget fighting game franchises from well-known AAA developers out there that still somehow don't have functioning online play. But the power of wanting to do right by your Hololive oshi can make wonders happen.

So far, the only criticism I do have has to do with the tutorial system: doing the inputs for some parts right seems to give you a pass even if what you're asked to do doesn't actually land, which might not be the most helpful thing for folks coming into this without prior experience in fighting games, so hopefully that gets fixed if possible.

I hope we can see more outta this game down the line, because in the short time I've had with it, it's genuinely one of the best fan games I've seen so far.

137866242.review:
OK, so...

With the little time I had playing this game, I can tell this is a very good game. Since obviously it's a F2P game, it has its flaws, but overall i think it's a good experience.

POSITIVES
*Good Music
No lies here. It's got some good tunes, and the vibes really stand out.

*Game has soul 
It looks and feels like love, care and sweat was put into this project. From the characters to the ambience, it all looks and feels amazing!

*Good use of Vtuber personalities/qualities in gameplay
 Again, since it's a F2P game, we don't expect every single Vtuber to be here. Nevertheless, It's good to see many recognizable faces (Coco, my beloved...) in this game. Looking forward for the extra content!

*Gameplay is fun
 Good gatling combos. They look original and very appealing to play.


NEGATIVES
-Commands/Motion Inputs are too easy...
So this is kind of a personal preference here, but the game is lacking in some technical variety when it comes to gameplay. While it looks very easy to pick up, it becomes kind of repetitive and boring. Not gonna lie, I was hoping at least one Charge character. I am used to play Charge Characters since Killer Instinct (SNES) and every time I pick a game, I tend to prefer those characters (i.e. Sabrewulf (KI), May (GG), Guile (SF))

-Little to No air combos
Again, personal preference. I was expecting some kind of air combos. I don't know why but I felt it had to be there, you know? Makes the game more fun and exciting.

-Difficulty/Balancing? (To be tested thoroughly)
 So, I tested Medium difficulty while plating with Coco against Korone. Every time I wanted to go a grab, Korone would just jump and avoid it. From 9 grabs i used, at least 1 connected. Not sure if it's the difficulty, but it really felt weird. One thing is for sure. At least, the character I'm finding difficult to play as is Coco. Her grabs are reaaaaaaaally telegraphed. Hoping for some balancing in terms of frames.

-Weird Character Choices/Not the characters I was hoping for
 I think most of these negatives are personal thoughts, but I feel some characters could have been fighters instead of assists. Marine and Mio are the characters I expected to be played. I hope the assists can become playable at one point and viceversa. Also, hoping for more characters from other agencies (Nijisanji, v-shojo maybe?) 

Conclusion:

These negative points are made from a constructive POV for the creators to look into them, so that the gameplay and overall game can improve in any way shape or form. As of right now, I haven't tested the Online funcionality of this game, but will do an update on it eventually. This is fantastic F2P Fighting Game in which heart and soul was poured into it. I really recommend it and I'm really hoping for some extra content!

137865577.review:
More of a neutral-rec than a no, honestly. If I actually was a Hololive fan, I might be able to power through the downsides, but I'm not. 

The animation feels pretty unpolished for gameplay purposes. If it were standalone animation, I'd be giving it a thumbs up, but I often had trouble figuring out when moves transitioned into their recovery period, or out of their startup period. Some moves [i]are[/i] really clear visually, but it's inconsistent.

The input buffer had me struggling to do invincible reversals, and REALLY didn't like overlapping inputs; one character I tried has a quarter circle back L+M move, and if I didn't input L and M on the exact same frame I got a completely different move. (And I do mean [i]exact[/i] same frame; the input display showed me getting the wrong move when I was one frame off.)

These two things probably wouldn't have been dealbreakers for me if I enjoyed the general design choices of the game, but nothing clicked with me enough to get me over them. Maybe you'll feel differently, but if I tried to keep playing it'd just be an exercise in frustration, I think.

137862719.review:
This is a fast and fun fighter with accessible controls and a cast of Hololive superstars with diverse fighting styles.  The 2D fighting is extremely satisfying and because it is so responsive with the cancel controls, even I, someone who is not really a fighting game player, can get in and enjoy the complex elements of combat in the game.  This is a game with high accessibility and I would imagine a high skill ceiling, meaning anyone can get into it, and more competitive players will find a lot of room to grow and get better at mastering their mains.

There is also a single-player roguelike story mode that allows you to take branching paths and attempt to get as far in as possible on one health pool across back-to-back fights all the while unlocking items to power you up and running across multiple choice pitfalls, buffs and double-edged swords.  This is a top-notch fan game and one that is of such high quality, that if I didn't know any better, I would say it was official.

Last thing I'll say is for Hololive fans, there is so much love here.  There are references galore and the use of sound clips from the Holomems and the numerous cameos, theme songs, original songs and memes scattered throughout the game are just fun to get Holobros deeper into the experience.

137859030.review:
First online match is a win!
I shall now retire and remain undefeated.

...

Jokes aside, this is a very fun game. I didn't even know this was a thing that was coming until I looked at Steam's popular upcoming section and found this game like 5 hours before it released. I'm not familiar with hololive but I'm not about to turn down a 2D fighter with cute anime girls, are you kidding me?

Main pros: 
- Movesets and animations are cute and funny. Things like characters dabbing or flipping you off with a smug grin as they walk away, eating a burger, sending your manager at someone to make them back off, throwing up a meme of the person they just grabbed, or an assist just straight up holding onto your legs and not letting you go. I especially love the cute hug animation as a throw.
- I enjoy that the match end screen is a streaming overlay, complete with a fake chat scrolling by and recommended videos shown underneath.

Main cons: 
- Navigating the menu can be a bit clunky sometimes, like I hit down once and it could move down two options. 
- Some things can be explained better, like on Fubuki's moveset her down+down+special has her eat a burger and the description of the move just says it "increases SSR for her next special." That's it. What's the SSR do? My only guess is that it increases the damage.
- Small roster, but I'm glad to see it'll be expanded. At least there's plenty more as a sub-roster specifically for the assists that can help mix things up.
- Only 4 stages. Hopefully we get at least a few more. 

Suggestions for the devs: 
- Do something about the menu navigation speed. I could barely tap down on the d-pad just once and it'd go down a couple options.
- Maybe add some curated tutorials for each individual character to introduce players to each part of their moveset.
- I'd love to see that end-match screen customized for each character. If it's meant to be like they're streaming the game, it feels weird that everyone you play as has the same design.
- Having player cards you can customize and display for the online portion would be nice. (Something along the lines of how DragonBall FighterZ did player cards, with an avatar, banner, title, stickers, borders...)
- A stats page for online matches would be nice. How many matches played, show a win/loss counter, track which character is your most played or must successful. 
- I'd like to see a sort of "Tournament" mode for players with a group of friends to get in a randomized bracket.

137858335.review:
Neat game and its free so it's great to pick up but so far I found a few things I don't like about it. Could just be the few characters I tried but I found myself not having fun very quickly. 

NOTE: This is from the Perspective of someone who just enjoys fighting games for the combos and single player content. I'm not a hardcore Online versus player. I just enjoy making combos, learning characters, and playing against the Ai to kill time. 

Now the first issue I had is the combo system. Its an ABCD system similar to games like Blazblue and Undernight in Birth but it lacks air combo potential. You get one hit in the air and that's it. You can do some cool Rejump stuff where you continue your combo with a delayed hit out of jump, but it left much to be desired in that front. Not a huge issue just for a casual player like me, I didn't enjoy the limitation.

Next is the Ai seems to input read. I know it's very popular to have input reading Ai to make it harder but to me it just sucks the fun out of it. If I get the advantage and go into a little block pressure, I don't want to be instantly grabbed out of delays or punished for trying to block. It feels bad personally but of course this is against Ai. It's to be expected, just a personal gripe for myself.

Now to the moves themselves, I mostly played Sora so experiences may differ. I found a lot of times the range on her moves were really subpar. For an easy to learn ABC Fighter you tend to push your opponent away easily in this game with a simple 5L2L5M2M - At that point I usually couldn't connect 5H or 2H with her. It really messed up the flow for myself but again that is likely intended, I just hate the feeling I get from messing up a simple string like that and eating a full combo after it.

I actually recommend the game and I can't wait to see updates and balance patches. Possibly extra characters? I don't actually know the devs plans but I wish them luck!

EDIT: Just wanted to add, I am not a fan of Hololive or any Vtubers really, I just enjoy fighting games.

Yes, you can turn the annoying voices off, but that's basically the same as either intentionally not experiencing the game as it was meant for
or you're just making the game slightly harder for yourself because fighting games have moves which rely on sound que's made by the character.

But again, i'm reviewing this as if it were to be more than just a fan made thing. 
The experience in my opinion 100% lies on if you like or don't like the hololive stuff. 
"If steam had a mixed review option id give it that at the very least"

Stuff that's neat:
[list]
[*]The usual character archetypes and their quirks are present: fireballs, tatsus, guns, rekkas, command throws... did I mention [b][i]guns[/i][b]?
[*]The netcode seems good thus far (even played an hour long set with a dude 8700km away lmao)
[*]Specials can be done both via motion inputs & simplified inputs (though I'm unsure at this point whether or not there's any penalty when using the simplified version)
[*]Training mode has pretty much everything you could ask for to experiment and lab
[/list]

[list]
[*]Auto-close lobbies when their owner leaves; right now it appears as though the lobbies stay visible in search for a while(?) even after their owner left, making empty lobbies far too common.
[*]Open/Community/Public lobbies (i.e. lobbies with more than 2 players) allowing people to play each other or spectate other people's matches.
[*]Queue functionality so as to not have to look for lobbies (ideally ranked/sbmm queue)
[*]Discord integration/rich presence?
[/list]
